review:
Puddle is a nice slick looking indy game. 
The premise is very simple: Get a certain kind liquid from point A to point B.
The liquid itself can not be controlled, but you can manipulate the environments in such the way that the liquid will start to move. 
Then you will have to navigate is through a trajectory with all kinds of booby traps and physics based puzzles. 
It's a very nice and calming experience, and the soundtrack and colorful graphics just make this a little casual game that is worth every single penny

review: I have only made it to the Sewers, but some of the chapters genuinely made me want to stop playing. It kind of reminds me of World of Goo, except the grossness overtaking the story, and no good music to distract from it. If those things were missing from World of Goo, I'd probably dislike it. If you like this game, then by all means, don't let a silly review stop you; but if you want a game that has fun music with simple gameplay, I would strongly recommend you NOT play this game.

review: Puddle - это уникальная головоломка-платформер, в которой игрок управляет жидкостью, перемещая ее через различные уровни, наполненные разными препятствиями и опасностями. Игра была разработана студией Neko Entertainment и выпущена в 2012 году.[hr][/hr]Основная механика игры заключается в управлении движением жидкости по уровням, которые представляют из себя лабиринты, полные препятствий. Нужно балансировать и управлять скоростью жидкости, чтобы добраться до конца уровня и собрать максимальное количество очков.[hr][/hr] В игре есть различные типы жидкости, такие как вода, лава, кислота и т.д., каждая со своими особенностями и характеристиками.Графика игры выполнена в очень красивом и приятном стиле, который напоминает живописные акварели. Музыка и звуковые эффекты добавляют игре дополнительной атмосферности и глубины.Игра предлагает более 40 уровней, которые понравятся как новичкам, так и опытным игрокам, желающим проверить свои навыки в управлении жидкостью. Отличительная черта игры - это высокий уровень сложности и уникальный геймплей.[hr][/hr]В целом, Puddle - это замечательная игра, которая порадует любителей головоломок и платформеров. Игра весьма оригинальна и интересна, с прекрасной графикой и звуковым сопровождением. Рекомендуется всем, кто любит нестандартные игры и готов испытать себя на прочность.

review: Today I finally completed Puddle, it's been an amazing decade of playing it. I first found out about puddle on the PS store back in 2010 on our old PS3, and I played the demo at least 1000000 times. I fell in love with Puddle, and when I first got steam few years ago, Puddle was the first game i bought, the full version blew me away immediately, and I played 3/5 of the game within 12-16 months! but it was all unfortunately deleted in 2018, which is why it says I only played for 51 hours, because i just speed-played through the game after restarting. But I eventually took a break for few months as I wanted to cleanse my palette a bit with Kerbal Space program, Cities: Skylines, and later Train Simulator, but I eventually finished everything except the last level, OH! was this a difficult goodbye for me, But I had to finish it, and today I finally did, and honestly I never felt so happy and sad simultaneously regarding a game, when the cut-scene of the game rewinding back in times played I was out of my seat, but then it stopped at the first cut-scene of the game, the coffee, and instead of spilling like it does at the beginning, the person actually picks it up and i almost had a break down as the game literally erases it's own events in a single cut-scene. I don't know how this paradox will play out if there is a sequel, which there better be in the future! But this game deserves a GOLD MEDAL! never did i expect a game about liquids to make me so emotional.

review:
This is a mobile/tablet ported 2D physics puzzle game where you must tilt the screen to make a glob of liquid flow into the target recepticle. 

The game offers 4K support but the developer didn't test it, the top left hand corner fills the screen because they didn't account for DPI scaling, which is unacceptable.   

Once more we see greedy mobile devs trying to screw over PC gamers. On Steam, this is $8 USD, on app stores, it's $1 USD. Mobile devs must learn PC gamers are not here to be gouged, and can't be expected to pay a premium for a mobile game just because it's been lazily dumped on Steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561198208680651', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1270, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1030, 'last_played': 1624218263}
review:
I originally played Puddle back around its release on Wii U. I remembered really enjoying this game, and apparently it isn't available on the eshop anymore. I decided to look for it, and I'm glad I was able to replay it. The game holds up really well. It offers a challenge, but I never had to use a "whine" which allows you to skip a level. The design of everything is really unique, and reminds me a bit of games like Little Inferno or World of Goo. The entire story is coherent, meaning you start out as coffee and by the end you're somehow playing as nuclear waste. It's really interesting, and the events that lead up to it are absurd as well. It's comparable to a butterfly effect, and it's fun to see what will happen next.

The gameplay itself is smooth, every liquid has a different consistency and mechanic that keeps the game from becoming boring. There's a sizable amount of content, and you can easily get a good 10 - 15 hours out of it if you're going for everything. I would recommend this game to anyone looking for a challenging unconventional indie game. I hope someday we'll get ports for modern consoles, but at this moment downloading it on Steam is the best method of playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996273719', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 797, 'playtime_forever': 446, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 444, 'last_played': 1601567949}
review:
[h1] Information / Review English [/h1]

Puddle is a puzzle game developed by Neko Entertainment.

[h1] Gameplay / Story [/h1]

The principle is similar to that of Mercury on the PSP: a viscous lump must be maneuvered to its destination with gentle movements. Here, however, you look at your nicely designed surroundings from the side and, as with LocoRoco, tilt the world by around 45 degrees so that the cloudy soup gets going. Another difference is the variety. Instead of just dealing with mercury, you are dealing with many substances. Coffee, water, pesticides and all kinds of explosive chemicals have to navigate abysses, open flames and other obstacles. Each section offers you demanding physics tasks to be solved.

[h1] Pro [/h1]

+ nice high-contrast design
+ cleverly designed courses
+ varied scenarios
+ many different types of liquids
+ tricky mix of balance and physics puzzles
+ Achievements and trading cards

[h1] Contra [/h1]

- Dangers often only recognized too late
- if the camera is too close you lose valuable drops

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Puddle offers you boozy physics puzzles that convince with interesting puzzles.


[h1] Information / Review Deutsch [/h1]

Puddle ist ein Puzzle Spiel, welches von Neko Entertainment entwickelt wurde. 

[h1] Gameplay / Geschichte [/h1]

Das Prinzip hat Ähnlichkeiten zu Mercury , damals auf der PSP: Ein zähflüssiger Klumpen muss mit sanften Bewegungen ans Ziel bugsiert werden. Hier betrachtet man seine hübsch designte Umgebung allerdings von der Seite und kippt die Welt wie bei LocoRoco um rund 45 Grad, damit die trübe Suppe in Wallung kommt. Ein weiterer Unterschied ist die Vielfalt. Statt nur mit Quecksilber hat man es mit vielen Substanzen zu tun. Kaffee, Wasser, Pflanzenschutzmittel und allerlei explosive Chemikalien müssen Abgründe, offene Flammen und andere Hindernisse umschiffen. Jeder Abschnitt bietet dir Anspruchsvolle Physik-Aufgaben wo es zu lösen gilt. 

[h1] Pro [/h1]

+ hübsches kontrastreiches Design
+ clever entworfene Parcours
+ abwechslungsreiche Szenarien
+ viele verschiedene Arten von  Flüssigkeiten
+ kniffliger Mix aus Balance und Physik-Puzzles
+ Errungenschaften und Sammelkarten

[h1] Kontra [/h1]

- Gefahren oft erst zu spät erkennbar
- durch zu nahe Kamera verliert man wertvolle Tropfen

[h1] Fazit [/h1]

Puddle bietet dir feuchtfröhliche Physikrätsel, die mit interessanten Puzzles überzeugen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198296178447', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 271, 'last_played': 1655548624}
review:
Puddle – Jest to gra zręcznościowo logiczna w której mamy za zadanie przeprowadzić płyn z jednego końca mapy na drugi koniec poziomu. Dodatkowymi smaczkami są tutaj ciekawostki dotyczące fizyki i chemii danych obiektów czy substancji, więc można stwierdzić że gra ma również walor edukacyjny.
Plusy + :
-Grafika (Grafika jest w miarę realistyczna chociaż może zahaczać o lekko kreskówkową. Pięknie zaprojektowane poziomy.)
-Fabuła (Dosyć nietypowe żeby w takiej grze była fabuła. Dowiadujemy się dzięki niej dlaczego sterujemy konkretnym płynem oraz jaki cel ma nasza misja.)
-Muzyka (Nowoczesne, elektroniczne brzmienia. Bardzo przyjemna.)
-Rozgrywka (Co ciekawe nie sterujemy bezpośrednio płynem tylko ekranem. Dzięki nachyleniu możemy manipulować płynem w którą stronę ma się poruszyć. Mechanika gry jest rozbudowana do takiego poziomu ,że każdy poziom zawiera w sobie coś unikalnego.) 
Minusy - :
Jak dla mnie minusów ta gra nie ma, chociaż jest to kwestią gustu. Jeśli dla kogoś jakiś poziom sprawia problem zawsze może go pominąć.
Podsumowując gra bardzo mi się podobała. Muszę przyznać że ta gra jest dosyć wymagająca, dla niedzielnych graczy może sprawiać problem z ukończeniem tego tytułu.Polecam.9/10.

review:
Um quebra-cabeças fora do comum, que requer agilidade e bons reflexos. O visual é bom, a jogabilidade é bem fluída (heh), os cenários são muito variados e a história é bem interessante, embora sirva apenas como pano de fundo para conectar as fases.

review:
Ожидала большего. Игра слишком простая, но претендует на хардкор, из-за этого она просто неприятна в прохождении.
Это вам не дзен с переливанием водички, не головоломка на какие-либо навыки и умения, не головоломка на реакцию, эта игра даже гемплеем не блещет. Это просто игра на задротство, не люблю такое.
Настоящий хардкор - это когда нужно применять умения, навыки, продумывать план действий. Тут такого нет, жаль.
Коль сделали настолько простенькую игру, то и искусственно сложной её не стоило делать. Нечему тут быть сложным, слишком мало для этого интерактива.

Однозначно не рекомендую, игра подойдёт только любителям трепать себе нервы и убивать время, тем же кто в игре ищет развлечения или какую-либо претензию на искусство советую проходить мимо.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057639245', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1527260764}
review:
Frustrating, possibly broken.

I bought Puddle hoping for an interesting little game about liquid physics. I instead got frustrated at almost every aspect of it. Puddle begins by demeaning you for picking the Normal difficulty, claiming that you’re a “whiner”, and that “whining and skipping is what you do best”. This is almost never a good move to pull, but even then, most games have the common decency to only do it on easy difficulties. Normal should be a default, yet Puddle derides players for not going straight to EXTREME. I’m already mad before starting the game.

Not that the game actually makes it easy, though. In fact, if it had an easy mode, I’d recommend it be called Playable. Because even Normal mode is borderline not. Instead of having any control over the liquid you’re following, you tilt the world to move it around. There’s potential here, definitely. But it’s poorly executed, as it requires an amount of precision that you can’t reliably get with liquid. As another reviewer noted, some levels seem like they’re designed not for liquid, but for a rolling ball. A game that doesn’t even explain its own controls shouldn’t be this precise this quickly.

In addition, levels tend to be unclear on what they want from you. On the first “boss”, for instance, I wasted most of my time trying to figure out what to do. It doesn’t help that the solution turned out to be very counterintuitive: I had to intentionally slam my water into the fire I’d been taught to avoid for all but one of the previous levels. I would have appreciated a lot more feedback or more indication of what to do. In general, any level or part of a level which isn’t purely about getting to the end tends not to explain itself well.

The camera, though, is the most frustrating part. I effectively abandoned plenty of liquid that the camera simply decided to scroll past, and in a few cases, offscreen liquid was the cause of my demise. There was even a level where I’d gotten all the liquid I could see to the exit, but a single offscreen drop fell onto some obstacle and failed the level. A more fixed camera would make this a better game. 

My one compliment? It’s gorgeous.

2/10

P.S. Neko Entertainment, the developer of Puddle, also made one of the most notoriously awful games ever: Charlie's Angels for GC and PS2. Had I done that research ahead of time, maybe I wouldn't have wasted my $8.

review:
Puddle is a rather strange platformer in the sense that instead of controlling a character we manage the flow of a specific liquid on each level. We do this by simply tilting the screen either left or right - nothing is easier (gameplay-wise) than using only two buttons to control our "hero".

Each chapter takes place in a different area and each time we manage the flow of a special liquid. We start with coffee than move onto water. You know water's biggest enemy is fire so we need to make sure we avoid hot areas otherwise our precious liquid gets evaporated. 

And this is where Puddle shines: in order to avoid boredom (after all, you always move from point A to point B) a special "ability" is assigned to the liquid we control. Later on we manage the flow of a weed killer at other times we have to carefully do the tilting as our nitroglicerin might quickly explode. 

The artwork and the music are both brilliant and the small videos showing how and why we proceed from one location to another is heaps of fun. I think a lot of people might find Puddle a bit awkward - it is certainly for a niche audience. Since it offers a rather unique experience I can wholeheartedly recommend it.

review:
Физическая переливалка

В описании из магазина допущена неточность - в данной игре мы управляем не жидкостями, а самим миром игры! Да-да, вращаем мир направо и налево, а жидкость перетекает сама.
В течении 48-ми (+1 секретный) уровней мы пройдем сквозь огонь, сточные воды, медные трубы, заросли с дионеями, человеческое тело, линии электропередач, лазерную установку, гравитационный ускоритель и другие препятствия, лишь бы перегнать минимальный объем жидкости из пункта А в пункт Б.
Успешное прохождение уровня напрямую связано со свойствами определенной жидкости (вода, нефть, нитроглицерин, раскаленная лава...) - нужно не испарить, не заморозить, не взорвать и не выплеснуть много из тары.
К тому же, на большинстве уровней поворотами мира мы не только перемещаем сам раствор, но и управляем объектом, в котором или рядом с которым он находится (плавильный котел, стеклянный шар, шланг пожарной машины, лазер и т.д.).
Игра мне показалось достаточно легкой (проходилась на нормальной сложности), режим лаборатории использовался только ради достижения, но больше всего я был раздосадован уровнями с, кхм, человеческими испражнениями и трупными экстрактами - ну зачем тут это надо?? 
 
7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198053953472', 'num_games_owned': 1944, 'num_reviews': 158, 'playtime_forever': 48, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48, 'last_played': 1512486775}
review:
Ever wanted to play a game where you don't control the character but you tilt the world? I've heard LocoRoco is good, play that instead.

Welcome to a platformer(?) where you control liquid. Cry as your liquid disappears offscreen which you could do nothing about and thus lost forever. Weep as you fail the level right before the end due to this constantly happening.

Isn't it fun when physics apply to your character(?) to such an extent that you don't feel like you have proper control? You would think so, but sadly when I actually played it I disagreed.

review:
I really wanted to like this game. But so many things are wrong here.

Gameplay-wise, all you can do is tilt your screen left and right. Which gives you minor control over the liquids. I hate that the automatic camera is going down the path so fast, causing you to lose your liquid just because it's out of your view. It sucks. I wish I had more control over the liquids' movement. Also, many liquids aren't working in the game like they'd work in real life. For example, water, coffee etc are too goo-ey and slow. You'd expect them to go must faster. I'd call them "imaginary liquids" because I feel like there's was not much research done about the actual physics of the liquids.

I bought it because it looked fun and pretty in the videos. But due to this frustrating gameplay I am not able to reach the final stages. It's not trash though. But it's the kind of game that will sit and rot in your library. Whether you should buy it or not depends on your patience.

I really love the art, and the music though. All those little sciency details and jokes are fun. It's very creatively done.

Overall, I'd say this game is beautiful, kiiinda fun, but average. The difficulty can also make you pull your hair, due to the gameplay flaws I mentioned above. 4/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066945741', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 262, 'last_played': 1498930448}
review:
Puddle is a platform-ish game. You have to move your puddle of liquid around the different levels. You don't have full control over the liquid though. The liquid moves depending on gravity and momentum (or other factors, depending on which level you're at). All you can do is angle the screen left or right, making the liquid move that way. The angling also helps you slow down or speed up your liquid. You only need 2 buttons, left and right. The liquids you control differ from level to level. Sometimes, it's a thick goo that sticks well together, othertimes it's an explosive goo that explodes when it crashes against a surface. 

Looking at the levels, they really look nice. Graphically, this game is beautiful. Gameplaywise though, some can feel really unfair. You can't see what's ahead, so finishing a level on the first try is very difficult. There are a couple levels where it's not very well explained what you need to do or how the physics have changed from the previous level. There are no checkpoints in any level, meaning you need to complete the entire level in one go. Most of the levels are however quite short.

The game doesn't store its info on the steam servers, so if you uninstall the game, you lose all your progress.

Looking back, I like the idea, but too many levels feel unfair and become unfun. I don't recommand this game. If you want to try this, buy it when on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040321744', 'num_games_owned': 3955, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 808, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 808, 'last_played': 1455077878}
review:
The game is obviously beautifully designed and the gameplay is refreshingly different, but my first time playing, I didnt give it enough time and thought it was boring. When I finally dragged myself back to it, I found one of the best indie games I have played. 

The controls seem simple at first  but you will soon learn there is more to it than just leaning the screen to make water fall down a hole. The hazards start requiring a bit more thinking and you will not always have the luxury of stopping to figure it out. The variety of liquids differ in more ways than just colour and viscosity. You may have trouble keeping some pooled together, others may dissolve or even explode in certain situations. Then there is the occasional change of physics to deal with and keep you on your toes.

This is definately not a game you should try to play through quickly as you will miss its full potential. Just finishing it is one thing but to get all achievements will require some patience and skill and a lot of planning. While difficult in spots, the game does not give the feeling of being impossible. You may pull some hair out but there is always the impression that you can do it if you just move slightly different over a section.

This is definately one of the more memorable and enjoyable indie games I have played. The achievements are well designed and give a sense of being rewarding, not just collecting. The game is challenging, but not near-impossible, so even if you doubt you gaming skills, I would still recommend looking at this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042646749', 'num_games_owned': 1460, 'num_reviews': 164, 'playtime_forever': 619, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 556, 'last_played': 1561676608}
review:
[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

You may have noticed that the publisher does not want to put a genre tag on this game, although the description does mention the word 'puzzles'. Well, I understand that but I will name the genre: [i]Puddle[/i] is a platformer game. Granted, it's a platformer game that uses unique mechanics in the sense that the 'avatar' is not a classic little man, animal, robot or a ball. But in the end all you do is guide something through a linear, straightforward parcours towards the finish line, while jumping (to avoid falling to your 'death') and while dodging stuff (to avoid getting 'killed' if you touch it). If that's not the very definition of a platformer game, I don't know what is. Assuming the word 'puzzle' implies at least a bit of thinking on how to solve a problem, there is no puzzling whatsoever in [i]Puddle[/i]. You always know exactly what needs to be done: there is only one way throug the parcours before you and you'll get through it by trial and error, not by puzzling your way out.

In [i]Puddle[/i], you don't control an avatar directly. You can only press a button to tilt the screen to the right or a button to tilt the screen to the left. As you tilt the screen, gravity will cause the 'avatar' to move. Most of the time, the 'avatar' has something to do with liquids. That means you need to guide either a liquid or a container containing a liquid through a parcours.

The level design is quite impressive. There is a lot of variety in the levels and they are all clearly designed with an eye for detail. But be warned, this is a very difficult game to master. Getting through the later levels will take a lot of practice until you know the parcours pretty much by heart, especially if you want to achieve the best score for each level to get the 'gold medal' the game awards, or for the Steam Achievement. 

[h1]Graphics and sound[/h1]

The graphics are quite nice and vibrant, and they managed to bring a lot of variety to the settings and their backgrounds, which is an impressive feat for a game with a pretty basic concept like this.

The music is all over the place. Sometimes I hardly noticed the music because it was soft and unintrusive, almost 'zen-like'. Other times, you get to hear techno music with a thumping bass beat. I have nothing against either of those music styles, but for a game I think they should pick one because alternating between two completely opposite genres is just weird.

[h1]On Steam's extra features[/h1]

[i]Puddle[/i] has 8 Steam Trading Cards. You'll get 4 just for running the game.

The Steam Achievements come in three varieties:
[list]
[*] finish a set of levels 
[*] make it hard on yourself e.g. complete all the levels with near perfection or finish a specific level with an extra condition to make it harder
[*] playful achievements just for fun
[/list]

[h1]Verdict[/h1]

[i]Puddle[/i] has a lot of strong sides, especially its graphics and its level design. But in the end, for platformer games I weigh the fun factor against the frustration factor. Great platformers are games that manage to provide more fun than frustration. To be a positive experience, it should at least be 50-50. And [i]Puddle[/i] fails to balance that equation. It's more like 60% frustration and 40% fun, maybe even 70-30, so I can't recommend this game in general. Only if you're a die-hard platformer gamer or a gamer looking for a nerve-wrecking challenge that [b]will[/b] have you cursing at your screen more than once (guaranteed!), [i]Puddle[/i] is right up your alley.

review:
[h1]Описание игры:[/h1]
Хардкорная игрушка основанная на физике. В этом маленьком инди шедевре нашей задачей будет перемещение различных веществ (иногда объектов) от старта к финишу (управлять возможно только меняя угол наклона экрана), стараясь при этом сохранить как можно большее количество вещества. Тут будет все - вода, лава, нефть, нитроглицерин, реактивное топливо и многое другое. Каждое вещество обладает своими уникальными свойствами и уровни построены так, чтобы мы эти свойства использовали по полной. Всего представлено 46 интересных, сложных уровней с двумя режимами сложности.

[h1]Плюсы:[/h1]
¥ Игра очень разнообразная. С одним веществом нам дается всего 1-3 уровня и только привыкнув к нему, мы идем дальше. Скучать уж точно не придется.
¥ Разнообразные мини-игры разбавляющие игровой процесс (каждые несколько уровней).
¥ Игра полностью на русском языке.
¥ Два вида сложности с юморной текстовой мотивацией :) Быть маленькой девочкой и сражаться за шоколадные медали или как мужик зарабатывать чистейшее золото? :)
¥ Интересные и сложные достижения (придется пройти всю игру на золото, а также сделать несколько дополнительных непростых задач).
¥ Удобное управление.

[h1]Минусы:[/h1]
¥ Музыка в игре живет своей жизнью. Иногда может пропасть на минут десять, иногда играет без умолку.
¥ Игра периодически вылетает.

[h1]Итог:[/h1]
Потрясающая игра которую мечтал пройти несколько лет назад на планшете, но в итоге все случилось в Steam и это было невероятно. Два дня не мог оторваться пока не прошел все. Было потрачено много нервов и десятки раз покрывал матом всех и вся, но прошел вдоль и поперек. Рекомендую всем и каждому.

[h1]Оценка: 10/10[/h1]

[h1]Послесловие:[/h1]
Если вам понравился этот обзор добро пожаловать в группу
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/uojer - тут вы сможете увидеть рекомендованные мною игры, другие обзоры, а также просто пообщаться в хорошей компании.

review:
A physics game where you control the tilt of the screen to make a small amount of liquid move through an obstacle course. You get a better score for both being quick and not losing too much liquid.

I thought it was creative and the levels were mostly well designed. Some players dislike the physics of the liquids, but I feel that it is pretty consistent for a simulation game. The camera can be downright awful sometimes as it attempts to keep as much fluid on the screen as possible, which is not a good idea when fast-paced areas cause your liquid to spread out as some parts trail behind. This makes some obstacles frustrating when you are less able to see them coming.

Overall, it's a difficult game and suffers from physics bugs from time to time. I enjoyed it however, and even managed to complete all the acheivments, so it's not impossible.

review:
Puddle ist ein wirklich gelungenes Spiel! Man kann Flüssigkeiten (später auch Anderes) bewegen indem man die Umgebung neigt, Dabei kommt es auf Geschicklichkeit an. 

Das Spiel punktet mit...
(+=gut | ++=sehr gut | +++=phänomenal)

+++...super Design (wirkt 3D - unterschiedlichste Leveldesigns)
++...Jedes Level hängt über eine kurze "Geschichte" mit dem nächsten zusammen
++...großer Abwechslung (durch Flüssigkeiten mit unterschiedlichen Eigenschaften)
+...einem gut umgesetzten aber nicht einzigartigem Spielekonzept
+...entspannender Hintergrundmusik
+...unterschiedlichen Schwierigkeitsgraden
+...dem "Labor" (wirkt wie ein Leveleditor - habe es aber noch nicht ausprobiert)
+...Sammelkarten (Dazu sehr schöne Hintergrundbilder beim Erstellen des Abzeichens)

Leider gibt es auch ein,zwei kleine Kritikpunkte:
(-=nicht so toll | --=schlecht | ---=fatal)

- für 7€ ist das Spiel trotz zahlreicher Level etwas zu kurz
- das Spiel hat seit 2014 keine Updates mehr bekommen, scheint also nicht weiter geführt zu werden
- ich würde mir einen Co-Op Modus wünschen (z.B. Wettrennen oder jeder kann nur in eine Richtung neigen, etc.)

Kurzum: für 7€ bekommt man 48 Level kniffligen Spielspaß mit viel Abwechslung und einem kreativen Design. Dabei unternimmt man eine Reise die alles enthällt. Von der Kanalisation bis in den Orbit. Nur etwas länger könnte die Reise gerne sein...

Das Spiel kahm mir aber sofort in den Sinn als ich einen Kandidaten für die Steam-Awards 2016 in der Kategorie "Ich fand das Spiel schon cool, bevor es eine Auszeichnung gewonnen hat" suchte und habe es direkt nominiert.

Endbewertung: 9,0/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198126182604', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 343, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 43, 'last_played': 1666053626}
review:
Game concept is interesting, but controls aren't smooth enough for this type of game. The rotating mechanism is too limited. Pretends to be deeply rooted in actual physics, but there are glaring issues with realism. All of this could be negligible, since the concept as I said is cool and the graphics are pretty. But the thing that bugs me the most, and the reason for the negative review. is the fact that the devs refer to the players as "whiners" if they want to skip a level. Also, the medals (completely unnecessary) for doing well in levels, in normal mode, are "fake medals made of chocolate". And on the surface of the medals you can read "whiners club". What??? 

This game reeks of self indulgence by the devs, elitism and despise for the player. Yeah, I'm sure they meant the whole whining thing as a "joke". The thing is, it's never a good idea to make fun of the people who buy your game. Who do you think you are? Self entitlement off the charts. Game makers who love what they do, care for the player. Because without the player, there is no game. You can be ruthless in a game, sure, like Don't Starve is ruthless, or Super Meat Boy or whatever hardcore game floats your boat. But those games are fair in their ruthlessness, and they don't make fun of you for losing or call you names. Really, if you feel the need of treating your public like this, maybe you should reconsider why you make games in the first place.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004615470', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 807, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 315, 'last_played': 1549756138}
review:
In its concept, Puddle proposes us, quite simply, to lead liquids of varying types from point A to point B, with, of course, a certain number of difficulties along the way and a limit for the minimum of liquid you have to bring to the finish line. Nothing particular here, but, as often, it is the way in which this concept is given form that makes the game really enjoyable. 

In the case of Puddle, the art design does a big part of the job. It is smooth, detailed, out of time, and even, on some rare occasions, a bit poetic. 
The game is divided into several environments corresponding to a theme, with in each 6 levels. It ranges from the sewers to flora to laboratories, even taking you inside the human body.
While on the environment, there is an electroacoustic music accompanying us in the perillous journey of the liquids, sometimes calm, sometimes dynamic, and I've found the soundtrack quite enjoyable overall (and I'm glad the devs made it available in a dlc, best to be bought during Steam sales).

In terms of gameplay, it couldn't be simpler: just tilt the screen left and right with the arrow keys for the liquid to move forward or backward. Of course, some parts will require that you measure your speed, or that you adjust yourself so as to make good use of the specifities of some of the environments (such as fans, slopes, sticky parts...). 
However, the nature of the liquid also comes into play, and it will force you to adapt to each one (water and organic wastes do not move in the same way, obviously). There are, more or less, as much types of liquids as there are environments, but you will find some variations on certain levels. 
The last level of each environment will give you a bit of a change in the gameplay, though. It acts as the equivalent of a "boss battle", without a boss, granted, but with added specificities in the task at hand (getting the right amount of two liquids in a glass bottle while it moves on a device, for example). A welcome change after struggling in the previous challenges. 

Regarding the difficulty, two settings are proposed: a relatively easy one (I insist on the "relatively"), in the form of chocolate medals (for the "whiny players"), or a hardcore one with metal medals. The rewards are based both on time and on how much liquid you were able to save.
If I didn't really suggest it so far, the devs don't take themselves too seriously, which is a good point in my book. 

To finish with, the negative things. There's only one that comes to my mind: the camera. 
At some points you will find yourself with your liquid being a bit scattered, either because that's inevitable (hopefully rarely) or because of a miscalculation. In these situations, the camera seems confused so as to how much of a zoom back it must make so that you keep an eye on what has been temporaly lost along the way. More often than not, it will keep its focus on the most forward part of the liquid, making it very difficult  for the player to gather it back. It is a bit annoying considering that, deadly obstacles apart, the game will consider a patch of liquid lagging too much behind as lost, and will remove it from your reserve. 
It doesn't spoil the pleasure of playing, far from it, but it is to be noted.

As a side note, and camera appart, the game is not buggy at all, and I don't find it redundant, at least with the way I play to it. For the length of the game... I've got a bit more than five hours on it at the moment of writing, and I have completed 5 out of 8 of the available environments on "whiny" difficulty.

To sum up, a lovely, humorous little game which is quite enjoyable. Best to be played little by little in my view.

review:
Это игра, в которой вы должны довести указанную жидкость (и не только) до конца уровня. Хоть делать нужно в каждом уровне, обстановка и правила часто меняются, так что наскучить не успевает:)
Сначала может показаться, что игра довольно легкая, но сложность постепенно нарастает так, что вы возможно дальше второй трети игры пройти не сможете. Лично я не смог пройти последнюю главу, там уже ад начался.
Каждая жидкость имеет свои свойства: влияние на уровень, массу и т.п. Все, что вы можете делать, чтобы поспособствовать ей добраться полностью или не очень - наклонять мир влево или вправо.
Что мне понравилось - что ситуации часто меняются и почти (или совсем?) не повторяются - то вам нужно уробрением выращивать растения, чтобы добраться до конца уровня, то течь органическим непойми-что по канализации, то течь лавой, которую нельзя охлаждать. Иногдв вместо того, чтобы дотеть до конца вроня, целью уровня может быть какое-либо задание (например налить сок в стакан так, чтобы было правильное соотношение компонентов). Уровни плавно переходят друг в друга, даже какой-то сюжет есть:)
Кстати - в игре есть битвы с боссами:)
Игру рекомендую, но не каждый ее пройдет до конца из-за сложности.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084674862', 'num_games_owned': 1182, 'num_reviews': 127, 'playtime_forever': 412, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 412, 'last_played': 1444071980}
review:
Puddle to historia rozlania się pewnej kawy. Zainspirowane efektem motyla króciutkie cutscenki pokazują, jak ten niewinny fakt zatacza szerokie konsekwencje, w rezultacie przekazując nam do dyspozycji różnorodne typy płynów o odmiennych właściwościach fizycznych. Obracając ekran, kołyszemy płynem, tak by pokonać tory przeszkód. Nim to się uda chwasty wyssą nasz cenny nawóz, nitrogliceryna wybuchnie przy zbyt szybkim uderzeniu, a refluksy z żołądka rozproszą napój w przełyku, nie mówiąc już o genialnych planszach w których jesteśmy paliwem rakietowym w próżni albo krwią w żyłach, gdzie zmieniają się zasady gry. Słowem ginie się często, ale po każdym zwycięstwie odczuwamy satysfakcję.

Nie zgadzam się z kategoryzowaniem tej gry przez Steam jako gra akcji/symulacja. Czytałam sporo komentarzy osób, które uważają ją za zbyt trudną, gdyż podchodzą do niej jako do gry platformowej opartej na refleksie. Ja widzę w Puddle przede wszystkim grę logiczną. Wymaga ona spokojnej głowy, opracowania strategii i próbowania różnych możliwości - gdzie przyśpieszyć, gdzie zwolnić i jak duży rozbieg należy wykonać. W porównaniu z bardzo podobnym Element4l sekwencje wcale nie są takie szybkie i nie wymagają podobnej perfekcji. Zaczynamy ze sporą ilością płynu, z którego większość spokojnie może się rozlać na przeszkodach. Żeby było jeszcze przyjemniej, choć odblokowujemy kolejne plansze jedna po drugiej, mamy 4 razy możliwość pominięcia poziomu, jeśli okaże się zbyt trudny - choć przyznam, że sama uparłam się z tego nie korzystać.

Przejście całości zajęło mi 7 godzin.

review:
Preface: I got pissed off at this game and decided to stop playing it.

Looking forwards to a relaxing or fun physics game involving liquid?

Well fuck you.

Immediately you are dropped into a seemingly unforgiving game world with arbitrary grading schemes and fail states. 
Your sole means of interacting with the game worlds is limited to rocking the screen in either direction approximately 30 degrees.

A terrible camera and poor controls means beating a level is often a process of memorization and brute force replaying, the game mechanics and liquids are never introduced sufficiently to feel competent with the game's systems before you are whisked off to other novelties. You may lose liquid by virtue of it just being off screen with the overly zoomed in camera - Which you do not seem to be able to control.

All of the liquid behaves like goo, it is slow moving and has ridiculous velocity. You can never move the liquid fast enough to be satisfying or to convincingly act like reality. The latter complaint is arguably not important as realism in Puddle's arcadey context is never a requirement but the slow and unrealistic physics movement seems to be a cover up of the game's incredibly short levels. 

This game may not be new and therefore cannot be fairly judged with today's standards, but it hasn't aged well and just feels like a crappy mobile port with good graphical polish.

A game that gives a number of 'whines' allowing the player to skip a level while insulting my intelligence with crappy controls and camera is a load of bollocks.

Final "word"
Sucks/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198111811696', 'num_games_owned': 1567, 'num_reviews': 179, 'playtime_forever': 17, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17, 'last_played': 1437843110}
review:
Я сначала играла в эту игру на Ouya и очень рассчитывала на её версию на Стиме (покупать на бесперспективной консоли как-то не хотелось, достаточно того, что я умудрилась купить саму консоль). Но эта версия расстраивает... Может, демо на Уе льстило игре. А может, были отличия в самих играх. Так или иначе, игра не доставляет никакого удовольствия любителю физических головоломок с жидкостями.

Управление в игре простое: наклонять экран вправо или влево, управляя вектором гравитации, чтобы таким образом заставлять двигаться жидкость через полосу препятствий. Необходимо довести хотя бы определённое количество жидкости до выхода. По окончании уровня эффективность прохождения оценивается тремя достоинствами медалей: медной, серебряной или золотой. Игра сходу сложная, но это плохо не само по себе... Плохо, что происходящее на экране почти не предсказуемо (вода рассчитывается как десятки частиц-капель, движущихся самостоятельно), а значит, хотя всё является следствием физической симуляции, управлять крайне сложно. Для игроков, склонных к перфекционизму, игра резко противопоказана: предотвратить потерю жидкости невозможно. Даже удовлетворить условия уровня мучительно: игрока ожидает ощущение беспомощности и отчаянные попытки хоть как-то повлиять на ситуацию. Другие игры про жидкость, например, "Archer Maclean's Mercury" для PSP, не обладают таким свойством.

И тут важна ещё одна особенность игры: разработчики издеваются над "недостаточно продвинутыми" игроками. В описании уровней сложности - прямо-таки хамство. Право получить доступ к следующему уровню, не проходя данный, называется "Нытьё" (Whine). Я вполне понимаю хардкорную культуру, но ни одна другая хардкорная игра надо мной так не издевалась, не предоставляя при этом достаточных средств контроля. Оно того не стоит.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970672461', 'num_games_owned': 2234, 'num_reviews': 195, 'playtime_forever': 256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 256, 'last_played': 1436297009}
review:
Puddle seems like an interesting liquid physics game.  It has a wide variety of liquids in different levels with different properties which you move by tilting the level, attempting to reach the end in the least amount of time possible while losing the least amount of liquid possible.  It should be fun, and at the beginning it is, though it quickly loses its luster.

To start with, the developers have the gall to give you "whine" tokens to skip levels and on the difficulty selection, go on about how playing on normal is for whiners.  Seriously?  I haven't seen such hostile behavior towards players since Phil Fish's "PC's are for spreadsheets" debacle.

The game starts off well, giving you a good variety of liquids to use and obstacles to overcome.  Goal times vary wildly, with some levels being trivially easy to get a gold medal on, and others near impossible.  Towards the end of the game, levels can become quite frustrating with precision "jumps" required using liquid that spreads out often beyond your view on the screen.  Then I got to the zero gravity levels, where instead of controlling gravity, you control slow-moving paddles to bat the liquid around in levels filled with walls that destroy the liquid.  It has to be the worst idea anyone has ever had for a physics game and stopped me from progressing any further.

Stay away.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043971033', 'num_games_owned': 624, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 466, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 466, 'last_played': 1436131552}
review:
Puddle is an interesting little game that's generally relaxing but occasionaly frustrating, and a decent timekiller which I tentatively recommend. Puddle -as you may have seen- is sort of a physics based puzzle/platformer. You indirectly control puddles by tilting the screen around. Most levels are obstacle courses which you must skillfully navigate to the end of as fast and efficiently as you can. When you complete a level, you are ranked by two criteria: time spent, and liquid lost. Though it's not necessary to get a medal to advance to the next level, ranking well can unlock certain achievements and objects for the ingame sandbox. Levels have numerous hazards which often correspond to the theme of the current chapter you are in. You journey from a kitchen table, to a laboratory, to a botancial garden, to the sewers, and to even more interesting locales.

As you progress, events of the game cause a series of reactions much akin to a Rube Goldberg machine (those 20+ step contraptions you see in old cartoons which ultimately do one simple thing) which wind up changing the liquid you control. In fact, your liquid can even become sticky rat goo, heavy contrast materials in the human body, and various gels! The great thing about each new substance is their new properties which reflect at least semi-realistically how they'd act in real life, and how each will have a special quality not seen in any other substance. For example, in the botancial gardens chapter you use both weedkiller and fertilizer, and you have to figure out when to kill plants, or when to grow something, or even how to tip a plant over by running your liquid across it. In my opinion the single greatest strength of this game is how well they keep things fresh by changing up scenarios, even if occasionally a substance may react a bit differently then how I'd expect it to in real life. The only examples I can definitely think of are the water and ink. They both should probably move faster, though the water should have a greater degree of cohesiveness due to the surface tension which ink lacks. The ink should be much harder to control and bleed everywhere. 

Now I'd like to quickly address some other aspects. I liked the visuals a lot. The visuals are a pretty big draw because each chapter has different color palettes, cutscenes are animated pretty well, and almost every level has it's own background. I only noticed a few repeated backgrounds or stage assets (ignoring levers and buttons of course). As for the music, I think it's okay. Not great. Suitable for the game I suppose but not really memeorable, moving, or something I'd listen to outside of the game. Next up is the sparse story. It's cool how everything flows together, but ultimately it could have used more personality. The story told is just a means to an end effectively, so I guess it really IS like a Rube Goldberg machine. Second to last gripe here would be the lack of content for the sandbox thing. It doesn't have a lot of accessible assets and it has a low cap on how much can be onscreen, despite it being a very small box, which limits creativity a bunch. Finally, the difficulty. Whoo boy can this game get tough. Only 2.3% of people have actually finished the game because the later levels can get mean. Some levels do require a lot of memorization or fine tuning, so you'll wind up having to run them multitudinous times, which can get pretty agravating.

All said and done, if you like the core concept, striving to improve your scores, and don't mind some particularly tough challenges now and again, then this might be worth your time. For $8 I'd say maybe to most people, but if it's $4 or under, everyone should give it a thought-though don't expect it to blow you away by any measure. 6.5/10

review: Puddle is a physics platforming game.  But instead of controlling a character, in the standard sense, your character is a liquid.  You control water, molten metal, coffee, and many other different types of liquids that all come with their special attributes.  The levels themselves range from super simple to super difficult, however, finishing the latter levels is not as difficult if you are not aiming for gold medals on all runs.  Achievement hunters, beware!  This game is very difficult to beat and achieve 100%.  I'd definitely recommend this game for that shear fact that it's original, it's beautiful rendered and the varying levels and liquids offer ever changing gameplay environments.  Definitely worth it if you find it at 50% or more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067095535', 'num_games_owned': 509, 'num_reviews': 144, 'playtime_forever': 275, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 272, 'last_played': 1656619272}
review:
Man hat im Laufe seiner Gamer-Laufbahn schon die merkwürdigsten/verrücktesten Spielcharaktere gesteuert, und eigentlich sollte einen erfahrenen Zocker nichts mehr überraschen können... Aber in Form einer Flüssigkeit wie hier in "Puddle" zu interagieren, DAS klingt in der Theorie dann doch ein wenig seltsam... Anfangs zumindest.

Obwohl es wenig bis gar keinen Sinn ergeben würde, haben sich die Entwickler von "Puddle" doch sowas wie eine "Story" ausgedacht:
Mit einem Becher voll Kaffee nimmt alles seinen Anfang, und im Laufe der insgesamt 50 Levels verwandelt sich der genannte Koffein-Trank in diverse neue Flüssigkeiten, die man in verschiedenste Umgebungen zum jeweiligen Ziel befördern soll. Dabei verschlägt es unseren "liquiden Freund" u.a. in den Wald, in ein Labor, sogar durch den menschlichen Körper oder in den Weltall - je nach Fallsituation als Wasser, Unkrautvernichter, Nitroglizerin (!), Pipi (!!) oder andere chemische Zusammensetzungen.
Auf eine gewisse Weise ist der Werdegang der Flüssigkeit recht witzig gehalten, das Ergebnis nach Beendigung der jeweilgen Themen-Welt wird durch leicht ruckelnde Zwischensequenzen mit der Einleitung des nächsten Schauplatzes verbunden. Humor mag vielleicht nicht zwingend von den Machern von "Puddle" eingeplant worden sein, aber ich für meinen Teil musste jedes Mal kräftig darüber schmunzeln.

So, und nun wollt ihr bestimmt wissen wie man bitte schön eine flüssige Substanz steuert, gell?
Die Antwort: Gar nicht. Sei es Wasser, Kaffee oder Schlag-mich-tot, man lenkt nichts davon direkt, sondern setzt es lediglich durch seitliches Links- oder Rechts-Kippen des Bildes in Bewegung. Dabei wird viel Geschick und noch mehr Fingerspitzengefühl abverlangt, da viele Hindernisse und Gefahren (Hitze, Frost, Elektrizität, Magensäure (!), ...) überwunden, gelegentlich auch Schalter oder andere Mechanismen aktiviert werden wollen, und dazu ist immer ein gewisses Maß an Be- oder Entschleunigung der Flüssigkeit nötig. Zudem muss immer eine Mindestmenge des zu rettenden Nass an seinen Bestimmungsort gelangen. Wenn das nicht gelingt, startet der aktuelle Level von Neuem.

Die anfängliche Leichtigkeit täuscht, denn mit weiterem Fortschreiten wird's immer kniffeliger und ausgefuchster, und dass mitten im Spiel immer etwas von der Flüssigkeit unwiderbringlich verloren geht ist zwar ärgerlich, aber nahezu unvermeidbar. Gerade in der zweiten Spielhälfte zieht der Schwierigkeitsgrad mitsamt Aufgabenstellung derart an, dass man hinterher einfach nur erleichtert ist einen Level nach zig Fehlversuchen endlich gemeistert zu haben.
Nach erfolgreicher Bewältigung eines Levels rechnet sich "Puddle" noch irgendwelche Werte zusammen, um den Spieler für seine Leistung abschließend mit Gold, Silber, Bronze oder einem einfachen "Erledigt"-Haken zu belohnen. Die höherwertigeren Medaillen verdient man sich je nach Schnelligkeit der Level-Absolvierung. Ob auch die gerettete Menge in die Abrechnung miteinfließt, kann ich leider nicht genau sagen, falls das überhaupt eine Rolle spielt.

In jedem Fall macht "Puddle" trotz hoher Trial-and-Error-Rate sichtlich Spaß, was auch zum großen Teil mit der liebevollen und extrem farbfrohen Aufmachung zu begründen ist. Die Level-Umgebungen sind richtig chic gestaltet und ganz und gar nicht starr oder steril. Immer tut sich was im Hintergrund, ständig herrscht hinter wie vordergründige Bewegung, und zusammen mit dem eigenen Spielfortschritt ergibt das erstaunlich stimmige Bild-Momente. Musik und Soundkulisse runden das Spielerlebnis positiv ab und machen aus "Puddle" einen audio-visuellen Appetitanreger der kleinen, aber feinen Sorte.

Die einzigen Kritikpunkt die ich am Spiel finden konnte:
- Alle Flüssigkeitsarten haben zwar leicht unterschiedliche Eigenschaften (Beispiele: Wasser verdampft, heisses Metall erkaltet, Nitroglyzerin wird bei hartem Aufprall instabil) die in der Tat zu beachten sind, die Trägheit bzw. die eigentliche Bewegungsphysik scheint dagegen stets die Gleiche zu bleiben. Außerdem hat man mehr das Gefühl einen dickflüssigen Brei zu bewegen - hört sich doof ab, ich weiss, aber es hätte ruhig etwas "flüssiger" sein dürfen. Hach Witz, komm raus... *g*
- Da die Kamera immer sehr nah und nicht selten etwas ungünstig positioniert ist, muss man jeden Level mehr oder weniger auswendig lernen, sich also jede Gefahrenstelle, jede heikle Position einprägen. Bei ganz anspruchsvollen Abschnitten einfach unumgänglich, was den einen oder anderen Spieler etwas frusten könnte.

Fazit:
Eine vermeintlich banale Spiel-Idee für echte Gamepad-/Tastenakrobaten. author: {'steamid': '76561198140299850', 'num_games_owned': 2332, 'num_reviews': 199, 'playtime_forever': 3662, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 960, 'last_played': 1617167246}
review:
If I wanted to suggest a game that would appeal to the widest range of players, from small child to the disabled to a brilliant adult engineer or gamer, it would be Puddle.

If you love to watch fluids flow, from coffee to rocket fuel or decomposed rat (yes, rat rot) and just have fun making them flow in strange, interesting or even funny ways, this game can be JUST that simple. And if you reach a level where more demands are made, and the player is unwilling to commit intellectually, they can take one of four “whines” (two whines on “extreme” skill level) in order to skip that difficult level. Each category grows more challenging as it progresses, and each group is VERY different from the preceding one. Each fluid flows differently, and is affected by factors such as fire or consumption by carnivorous plants (though gratefully not on the same level.) A glass globe filled with water must be handled with great delicacy, as must nitroglycerin, both in the Laboratory section. (But it may also be necessary to CAUSE small amounts of the nitro to detonate to proceed. Or to sacrifice fluids to make a branch break to facilitate a pathway, or destroy a container to free a fluid to flow. Such skills are a bit beyond the “small child” level.) Some fluids are highly flammable, but can also be extinguished if action is taken quickly. Sometimes “winning” may consist of sending a flaming mass of liquid pouring quickly over the finish line (though not likely with a high score).

For those seeking an intellectual challenge on an intensely scientific level, this game is just a little slice of heaven. While in its simplest form this game is simply gravity acting upon fluids, Puddle vastly exceeds the simple. Anyone not familiar and comfortable with the phrase “water seeks its own level” may find themselves at a severe disadvantage, but understanding Newton’s laws of motion is REALLY helpful. Ultimately, as there are only two buttons, there are also two goals: get as much of the original fluid mass to the finish line as quickly as possible. If the constantly monitored fluid level drops below a preset amount, you lose. If it doesn’t, you WIN! What you win is gold, silver, copper, or simply completion. The scoring is given in the form of a rather sophisticated graph where the meeting points of the two measured variables are displayed in comparison to the three award levels. Players are also informed if their score is a new record.

It takes skill and intelligence to use the force of gravity alone to keep the fluid in a compact mass, especially when it’s gravity trying to spread it out and break it into separate droplets. On several game levels that may be helpful, on others, the deal breaker. Some fluids, such as water, slosh about and need to be “damped” (as is done with the swinging weight hanging from an overhead crane.) Often trailing bits of fluid must to sacrificed so that the leading mass isn’t slowed as it crosses flame, or other reductive forces. Knowing that science will help the trailing fluid to move faster, thus pushing the slowly moving leading fluid quickly over a destructive force is often critical. So is trusting that momentum will keep fluid moving uphill if direction is changed as early as possible, helping the full mass end up downhill faster than if you waited. The real challenge in this game is trimming milliseconds off the time, and adding the tinniest fraction of a drop to the mass by speeding it along instead of waiting that extra tenth of a second.

For many disabled or impaired players, this game is “perfectly” simple. All that’s required for play are the left and right arrow keys to tilt the world displayed onscreen (though split-second timing can be VERY crucial in many levels.) I have played exclusively on the Mac version, and Puddle does not appear to have adaptability for colorblind players. The game is very nearly photo-real with a wide range of colors, and the fluids themselves often change color during play. I can’t speak for how this might be an issue for the “color-impaired”.

There are some issues with Puddle. If your fluid gets broken into several masses, the camera may ignore the one needed for completion. I’ve had to manually close games when I was unable to even know where the remaining fluid was, much less maneuver it effectively. On my Mac the mouse is useless in the menus. The menus themselves need LOTS of work. It would also be nice if the score you were trying to beat was shown in some way on the score screen, or better still, in the graph. To see what scoring you’ve achieved on each level takes several steps more than could possibly be necessary. Some levels (Human Body: Tension & Stout Hearted) are FAR more difficult and cumbersome, bordering on impossible, on my Mac than what I’ve seen on YouTube.

All in all, the BEST $2.49 I’ve ever spent on a game in my life. I expect to be playing this game for quite some time to come.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026408440', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 175, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 175, 'last_played': 1424623985}
review:
I have mixed feelings about this game. It's definitely a great game as far as design goes. The controls are simple yet unexhaustable in ways you can use them for everything (this is a two button game). Physics are also always nice to have in a game, and this one is based around it so that's a plus.

There are two real problems I have with this game. The first one is that the game is very unforgiving, in a bad way. When you fail the level (which means losing too much of your liquid, which I'll come back at in a moment) you will have to redo the entire level. Most of the levels are pretty long, but only because parts of it are relatively easy but very slow. Failing at a harder part in the level (usually the end) will mean you will have to do over maybe 3 minutes of easy and slow work. If you're a failure at games like me, that gets really frustrating very fast. Now on to the second problem I have with the game, the fuzziness. Everything in this game is based on the amount of liquid you can get to the end, but the game itself decides whether liquid is part of the main group or not. Usually that means that when there is a blob of magoo ahead of a smaller blob of magoo that you still wish to move to the main one, you cannot because it ends up moving out of the view. I have failed levels a lot of times because of not being able to see all the liquid. Keeping liquids together is one of the main objectives of the game, but should not be a pain.

I would still recommend this game purely for the fact that the easier levels are quite fun. If you don't have to restart levels countless times you can really appreciate them. It's a well designed (in visuals and levels) game with mechanics that are new and exciting (at first), but I would really like to see more of it than I could have in my few hours of playing.

review:
[i]"Teče voda, teče strání
a suchý list plave na ní,
teče voda, teče strání,
sám sebe se ptám,
jak ta voda strání pádí,
nezastaví ji sto kádí
a ten list, co plave na ní,
nejsem-li já sám – HEJ !"[/i]
-- Jíří Schmitzer, Kaluž


V Puddle jste.. kapalina. Obvykle. Nemusí jít nutně o vodu, v průběhu hry dostanete na starosti i kaluž kyseliny, lávy, hnojiva a dalších. Vaším úkolem je dotéct na konec kola a co nejméně tekutiny po cestě poztrácet. Jediné, co můžete dělat, je naklánět prostředí a využívat gravitace a fyzikálních vlastností vám svěřené louže.

Prostředí jsou dost pestrá, autoři využili opravdu leccos. Často se mění, takže nudit nezačnou. Pokud se ovšem někde nezaseknete - některá kola jsou vyloženě o tom naučit se dělat správnou věc ve správný moment metodou pokus-omyl, což může být frustrující. Slabší povahy ale můžou využít "whine" a kolo přeskočit. Silnější povahy zatnou zuby a zkusí to znova. 

Grafika je pestrá, měnící se prostředí jsou opravdu zajímavá. Fyzika funguje taky hezky (ještě aby ne) a ovládání je zvládnutelné (2 tlačítka nejsou moc.. do cesty se vám bude spíš stavět fyzika vaší louže).

Hře by nebylo moc co vytknout, jen mám pocit, že po jejím dohrání se k ní už nevrátím - kola, která jsem prošel lehce se mi znovu hrát nechce... a kola kde jsem byl zaseklý taky ne. Radši než se učit přesnou ovládací sekvenci, abych získal medaile a předměty do jakési laboratoře, to už si radší pustím zase něco jiného;-) Ale za ten jeden průchod Puddle stál. 

Za kolik stojí: <2€

author: {'steamid': '76561198031234423', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 274, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 267, 'last_played': 1421695902}
review:
Puddle is this kind of game I wish I could recommend.

It's a physics based puzzle game with a great concept, it's creative and honestly, I did have some fun while playing it. But there are flaws that can't make me recommend it (or at least to its full price).

The point is basically to make some liquid go from point A to point B, while being confronted in different situations and environments. 
Depending of the level, the liquids are different, with their unique properties, which makes them interact differently with their environment... although I thought that most times, whether they were different or not, the same physics applies to them.

While the game has a great concept and there's a certain variety of levels for the player's entertainment, the game gets hard very quickly, and it becomes quite irritating to fail again and again a level. 

You can never know what's ahead, as the camera is too close to your liquid. It also seems to follow the liquid part that's in the front, and never gives you a big picture, which is pretty annoying if you have most of liquid left behind.
Also, the physics and at times, whole level design, are really clunky, which is of course a real problem for a game as such, where you need to be really precise with where you take your puddle.

About the great difficulty, and I’ll be frank, what immediately irritated me when I started the game: the “casual” or easy mode, is called a mode for “whiners”, where you’re allowed to skip a limited amount of levels and you won’t appear in the leader boards. 
To me, calling the casual mode as a mode for "whiners", where you "whine" when skipping a level, is an insult to all gamers, casual or not. It's aiming at all the ones just wanting to enjoy their games without pressure, nor wanting to have their names in some leader board unlike the normal mode (which, curiously, they haven’t renamed…).


In short: Great concept, very interesting ideas but quite clunky physics which is a great problem when you need to be precise. The game gets difficult too quick for casual gamers, or as they put it, “whiners”.

review:
Very difficult game made even worse by minimal instructions. The designer expects you to just figure it out via trial and error. It is very difficult to plan your moves ahead of time to avoid hazards because you have no control over the camera or how far ahead you can see. At least a level preview would have been nice for this. This destroys the sense of control and that is something gamers despise greatly. To make matters worse, they have a skip feature if a puzzle has you thouroughly stumped. Insultingly they called the skip a "whine". PIssing off the gamer who may or may not recommend you game is a bad business plan and you just lost a recommendation here are a result. The designers seem to have forgotten what makes a game fun and replayable.

BOTTOM LINE: Avoid this game as it is not the relaxing experience it should have been. Definitely avoid if you hate games that require a lot of repetition to beat.

review:
画面を左右に傾けることで、様々な種類の液体(だけではないけど)を、素早く、出来る限り多くゴールまで運ぶのが目標。アクションというよりはパズルの要素が強い。
液体を失う要因には熱による蒸発から液体自身への衝撃による爆発まで様々あり、それらを回避しながら効率的な動かし方を考えていく必要がある。
難易度はNormalとExtremeの2つがあり、後者では液体の速度変化が小さくなったり、液体が散らばりやすくなったりする。どうしてもステージがクリアできなければ、4回(Extremeは2回)までwhineで飛ばすことができ、あとでクリアすればまたその分のwhineが使えるようになる。ちなみにSteam実績はすべてNormalでも達成可能。
ステージが始まる前に液体の性質とステージに関する説明があるが、少々読めなくてもステージにある標識などで理解できる。
音楽や効果音はステージにもよるが、全体的に眠りを誘うような感じで落ち着いている。

全ステージをクリアするのはそれほど難しくないが、Extremeでメダル集めをやろうとするとかなり歯ごたえがある印象だった。ただ、1ステージがかかっても5分ほどなので、短い時間でサクッと遊ぶ分にも手軽なゲームだと思う。
やりこむつもりがなければ、サントラ込みで980円は少しだけ高いかもしれないが、物理系パズルが好きならぜひおすすめしたい。

review:
Great concept and all, but terrible execution.  Levels require an annoying amount of precision that just can't be achieved with liquids... at least not liquids as non-cohesive as these.  What's more, some levels seem almost designed to force you to lose large amounts of liquid, such as levers that you have to "pull" dropping down and bottlenecking the liquid behind it while the rest of it races forwards for no clear reason.  Some of the levels seem like they were tested for use with a solid ball, and the liquids were put in there as an afterthought.  What's worse is that most levels require you to know what's ahead and plan for it even though you've never seen it; and many of those require you to be at some particular speed between letting the liquid just do its thing and full tilt.

And the kicker is that the game has the nerve to call you a "whiner" (read:  about as close to "little b*tch" as it can while keeping a kid-friendly rating)  when you want to play [i]normal[/i] mode or can't get past the clunky controls and poor level design.  

All in all, 5/10.  Absolutely great concept, but the poor controls and poorer level design just make it an infuriating game.

review: Another patience-testing physics game with a frustrating control scheme that's probably more suited to a tablet. The liquid in [i]Puddle[/i] moves at such an awkward, sluggish pace that predicting the necessary movements becomes a chore of trial and error. Occasionally, the liquid will respond in a completely bizarre way, travelling uphill for no apparent reason. The camera is also confusing, sometimes following the liquid at the front and other times following the largest mass of liquid, which can make it either impossible to control the majority of liquid or impossible to see what's coming next. I guess [i]Puddle[/i] could be entertaining for anyone who enjoys failure and repetition, but for everyone else it's probably worth giving a pass.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030080447', 'num_games_owned': 1277, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 477, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 373, 'last_played': 1441558626}
review:
Puddle is a puzzle-platform game that makes clever use of advanced physics to let you move all kinds of liquids through different obstacle courses. While the idea itself sounds rather straightforward, the execution is certainly not. The first levels, using water as a liquid, are not too difficult and I thought "tihs game is going to be a piece of cake". But how wrong I was (am actually). Difficulty goes up steeply and the developers have really thought of all kinds of possible liquid and obstacles to make life ever more difficult. Water, oil, goo, fertilizer, nitroglycerine, all pass the review and all ask for a different approach. This keeps the game interesting, since the visual context changes accordingly to the liquid being processed. And since the visuals are really outstanding for an in essence static background, the developers have done a good job.

But after a couple of hours, my interest in the game diminished since I got tired of the trial-and-error which seemed to be necessary in some of the later levels. So I let the game rest for a couple of weeks, and picked it up again recently. Now I pick up some levels ad random and try to get more of the Steam achievements, which are a clever addition to the game. All in all, this game is a nice sideway away from any larger-scale gaming projects, but don't expect anything more really. If Steam reviews would have a "neutral" option, this one would get one. But in the end I give it a "thumbs up", if only for an original idea being well executed, with a lot of love for the project being involved.

Gameplay: 17/30 (interesting at first, but too difficult after a time)
Graphcis: 16/20
Sound: 5/10
Longelivety: 5/10
Technical/stability: 16/20
Personal appreciation: 5/10

Overall: 64/100

author: {'steamid': '76561198058800709', 'num_games_owned': 130, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 155, 'last_played': 1513208952}
review:
TL;DR [b]Simple controls but unique gameplay because of the particularities of the liquids. Not only liquids so it diversifies the gameplay. Not for easily disgusted and non-patient people. For physics lovers. Worth 8$. I highly recommend.[/b]

Here's Puddle, a game I found during the Paris's sales. At first, maybe it's hard to decide whether or not to buy it. I mean, you only tilt the screen to the left and right, moving liquids, but this game is incredibly... incredible! So yes, this is a "I go from this point to another" game, but you don't directly control what you lead to the end.

Let me explain myself. Basically, you control a liquid by tilting the screen to the left and right (I think this game was first designed for mobile). Sounds boring, uh? Well destroy this thought right now. Not only are the graphics awesome to my eyes, but the every liquids are different and this creates unique and diversified gameplay. You have coffee, ink, lava, even a liquid that doesn't fall from the top to the bottom but... from the bottom to the top! Some are heavy and falls quickly, some are compact and stick to stuff, some explode... I couldn't even name all the particularities off the top of my head, there are so much! And I haven't even finished the game while I'm writing this!

However, people that are easily disgusted shouldn't play this. The body chapter made me slightly wince and I myself am someone that is not easily disgusted by this kind of stuff. The following chapter is the sewers and ain't really better. Also, if you're not patient, unless you want to start to be patient, this is not really a game you should be looking for. However, if you're ready to spend a chunk of your time on difficult levels, go on. The game offers to use "Whines" to skip levels but you know, I want to keep my honor and not use them to be proud to say "I completed all the Puddle levels"...

About being patient, some levels are special sometimes, and also harder. They usually are at the beginning and end of every chapters. There, you don't always control liquids but most of the time, there always are liquids involved. One time you control a souvenir ball where the liquid is inside the ball, another time you control lasers and need not to burn the liquid in addition of doing something else at the same time to finish the level... Consider those levels as introductions and bosses. I really like the idea.

If I revise everything, Puddle has reaaaally simple controls but the particularities of the liquids make the gameplay unique every time. Also, you don't always control liquids, so it diversifies the way to play. But of you're not patient and easily disgusted it's not the game for you. If you're a fanatic of physics, however, you should like it.
I really recommend this game. Worth 8$. Could've been 5$, but 8$ is alright too.

review:
A great game that can be relaxing while complex and challenging. Puddle is a pretty versatile casual game. With beautiful graphics, great physics engine and very well designed levels it keeps itself fresh and fun to say the least.

The controls are limited, which might be a bit frustrating if you want to get the best score in a level. However, levels are well planned, letting the player interact constantly with it.

Puddle lets you explore two main ways to finish a level: take a while and focus on keeping the most of the fluid intact or rushing through the level to get the best time. Yet, you'll have to combine both ways, to make the best score. 

The puzzle characteristics of the game doesn't make it boring, on the contrary, it requires a good use of its dynamics to complete them.

While not being exactly immersive, the audio and graphics create a very pleasant atmosphere that merges perfectly with the entire purpose of the game.

A Bit short but a great choice for those who like casual and puzzle games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198130514798', 'num_games_owned': 1417, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 96, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1405901942}
review:
It's a great game. It looks awesome. It sounds awesome. It's challenging.

... but I don't like playing it. I think I understand why.

Remember those old wooden games where you had to get the little marble past a series of holes in a wooden maze [image here: http://img0.etsystatic.com/008/0/7167039/il_570xN.405487188_jh4y.jpg ]? Those maze games were the bane of my childhood. Puddle shares a lot of similarities with those maze games.

Much of Puddle is skill-based in the same way those maze games were; you have to gain a "feel" for which way this thing is going to travel, calculate when to change its direction and perform the series of maneuvers perfectly or you've frakked up and have to start over. If you let your blob hit a wall and split off into 6-7 little blobs, that's it, you might as well start over.

It's a little too frustrating for my tastes.

review:
Инди-игра, играющая с различными жидкостями и физикой.
Немного можно сказать об этой игре: основная идея здесь заключается в том, что нам нужно провести какую-либо жидкость в конец уровня, обходя при этом различные препятствия, взаимодействуя с различными механизмами и стараясь сделать все это как можно быстрее и с минимальными потерями этой самой жидкости. Всего в игре 48 уровней (и один секретный), но, как это не удивительно, практически все уровни различаются друг от друга: в одном нам нужно тушить горящие ЛЭП, в другом - провести лекарство через пищеварительную систему человека, в третьем - управлять ракетным топливом в невесомости. У каждой жидкости есть определенные свойства, которые могут помочь или затруднить прохождение уровня, что, опять же, не дает геймплею повторяться. 
Многие жалуются на "глупое управление", но, как мне кажется, оно здесь простейшее и не является какой-то проблемой. Так что если вам хочется посмотреть на интересную игру, в основе которой лежат законы физики или в вас просто живет дух экспериментатора, то Puddle должна вам приглянуться. 7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198014300838', 'num_games_owned': 117, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 375, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 338, 'last_played': 1657149519}
review:
Puddle is a Physics based puzzle game where you control various liquids, by tilting the screen using the left and right arrows on your keyboard. Each liquid has it's own properties, and you must use those inorder to navigate your way to the exit, past obsticles and hazards all the while keeping as much substince as possible. Personally I thought the first half of the game was actually kindof fun and creative. Each "chapter" gives you time to learn about the new liquid, and the transitions between each are quite creative. However besides the human body chapter, the second half of the game is just painfully hard. I'm not saying I don't like a little challenge now and then, but when you have to be almost flawless to get enough liquid to the end, it's kindof off putting. The Foundry level is what really tested my patients, so much in fact that 6 months ago (atleast) I gave up and didn't  even atempt trying until today, and beat it. Never before has a game made me so frusterated, that I just gave up, and I'm a very patient person. Ask anybody! Now the game does allow you to skip upto 4 levels if you find them too hard, but I could not bring myself to do such a thing. While this game does have a a rather high difficulty, it looks very preaty and is quite fun at the begining. I would not recommend this to anyone who does not have the patients to complete the game, but if you are willing (and it's on sale) then give it a look see. It might just surprise you. Still cheaper on iOS though.
